questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common mode of transmission of tuberculosis to the endometrium?
questions.explanation:
Endometrial tuberculosis is most commonly acquired by direct spread from the fallopian 
tubes. Hematogenous spread is thought to be the process by which the tubercle bacilli implant 
into the mucosa of the fallopian tubes and subsequently affect the endometrium by direct 
extension. Female genital tuberculosis is an important cause of significant morbidity, short and long-term 
sequelae especially infertility. Genital tuberculosis usually occurs secondary to pulmonary 
(commonest) or extrapulmonary TB like gastrointestinal, renal, skeletal, and miliary TB. However, 
primary genital TB can rarely occur in women whose male partners have active genitourinary TB 754 
Sold by @itachibot (e.g., tuberculosis epididymitis) by transmission through infected semen Most common site involved in secondary genital TB is fallopian tube (90-100%) >endometrium 
(50-80%) >ovaries (20-30%) >cervix 5-15%) >vulva. The most common symptom of 
genital TB is infertility. Causes of infertility in genital TB: • Tubal blockage • If tubes are patent, then also infertility occurs due to loss of tubal function. • Tubercular endometritis causes uterine scarring resulting in the destruction of the endometrium. • Ovarian damage with poor ovarian reserve and volume A laparoscopy and dye hydrotubation (lap and dye test) is the most reliable tool to diagnose 
genital TB, especially for tubal, ovarian and peritoneal disease. The test can be combined with 
hysteroscopy. Multiple drug therapy ( ATT regimen provided by DOTS) in adequate doses and for sufficient 
duration is the mainstay in the treatment of TB including genital tuberculosis.

questions.question:
Question 3: A young woman with fertility issues is diagnosed to have genital tuberculosis. Which of the 
following statements is false about this condition?

options.a: The causative agent is Mycobacterium bovis
options.b: It generally occurs secondary to a primary focus
options.d: It commonly presents as a unilateral condition

questions.explanation:
Genital tuberculosis is a bilateral condition. It can be caused by both Mycobacterium tuberculosis (95% cases) and Mycobacterium bovis (5% 
cases). It almost always occurs secondary to a primary focus elsewhere in the body. The most 
common primary focus is lungs > lymph nodes > abdomen > generalised miliary 
infection. It mostly spreads hematogenously. Lymphatic spread is also seen sometimes. It can rarely spread 
by direct contact with the affected intraabdominal organs or peritoneum. The fallopian tubes are the first to be affected. The disease subsequently spreads to other genital 
organs and the peritoneum. This is followed by the involvement of bilateral pelvic lymph nodes. 
Vulvovaginal involvement is usually secondary to uterine involvement. The most common presentation of genital tuberculosis in the reproductive age group is infertility.

questions.question:
Question 4: What is the most common presenting symptom of genital tuberculosis in the reproductive age 
group?
questions.explanation:
The most common presentation of genital tuberculosis in the reproductive age group is infertility. Genital tuberculosis mostly presents in young women in the reproductive age group. It can 
present as: • Infertility is the only complaint in 35-60 % of cases. Of these, 75% of women present with 
primary infertility. • Menstrual abnormalities are seen in 10-40% of cases. • Asymptomatic in 10% of cases. 755 
Sold by @itachibot • Other symptoms like fever and malaise can be seen. The treatment of infertility in women with genital TB depends on the condition of the 
endometrium. If the endometrium is receptive and the uterus is normal, then assisted 
reproductive techniques such as in-vitro fertilisation can be tried. If the endometrium is 
unfavourable then surrogacy may be considered.

questions.question: Question 5: In a patient with tubercular salpingitis, which of the following statements is false?

options.a: The tubes are enlarged, roughened, and may show presence of greyish tubercles
options.b: The ampulla of the tube appears dilated with the fimbrial end open and pouting
options.c: The granulomas and hyperplasia seen can be mistaken for carcinoma
options.d: The fimbriae are commonly involved in advanced tuberculous salpingitis

questions.explanation:
The fimbriae are often spared even in advanced forms of tubercular salpingitis. The involvement of fallopian tubes is 100% and bilateral, secondary to hematogenous spread. The 
ampullary part of the tube appears dilated with the fimbrial end open and pouting. This gives the 
characteristic tobacco-pouch appearance as seen in the image below. The external surface of the tubes are enlarged, roughened, and may show the presence of greyish 
tubercles. The cut section shows yellowish-grey caseous matter in the lumen. Sometimes, 
serosanguinous fluid can also be seen in the lumen of the fallopian tube. This is called tuberculous 
hematosalpinx. On histopathological examination of the tubes, granulomas and chronic inflammatory infiltrate 
with hyperplasia is seen. This could be mistaken for malignancy as it also produces a similar 
histological image.

questions.question:
Question 6: An 18-year-old girl presents with a history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain 
and amenorrhoea for six months. On examination, a pelvic mass is felt on the left side and 
signs of ascites are positive. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with abdominal pain, amenorrhoea, pelvic mass and ascites is 
suggestive of genital tuberculosis. Genital tuberculosis: 756 
Sold by @itachibot It is caused by M. tuberculosis and almost always occurs secondary to primary infection elsewhere 
in the extragenital states. The sites and frequency of involvement are as follows: • Fallopian tubes (90-100%) • Endometrium (50-60%) • Ovaries (20-30%) • Cervix (5-15%) • Vulva and vagina (< 1%) Presentation is variable and it can be asymptomatic in 10-20% of cases, infertility, menstrual 
irregularities, abdominal pain and mass, vaginal discharge, fistula formation, ectopic pregnancy 
and ascites. The mass is made up of rolled-up omentum that is adherent to the uterus and adnexa. Constitutional symptoms such as fever, weakness, anorexia or night sweats may be present. Investigations: • CBC, ESR and Mantoux test • Hysterosalpingography shows a lead-pipe appearance of the fallopian tube, calcification of the 
tube, beading and variation in the filling, cornual block, jagged fluffiness of tubal outline and 
tobacco pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx. • Laparoscopy establishes the diagnosis of genital TB. It shows tuberculous lesions and 
perihepatic adhesions (if present). Differential diagnosis: • Ovarian cyst, broad ligament cyst or encysted fluid • Pelvic inflammatory disease • Ectopic pregnancy • Carcinoma cervix • Elephantiasis of the vulva • Pregnancy • Puberty menorrhagia and postmenopausal bleeding • Fungal infection and sarcoidosis Management: It is treated with anti-tubercular therapy for 6 months (DOT strategy): Indications and contraindications for surgery: Types of surgery include vulvectomy (if vulval hypertrophy is present), removal of the adnexal 
mass, drainage of pyometra and fistula repair. TAH+BSO is rarely required nowadays. Tuboplasty is contraindicated. Option B: Ovarian tumors usually don't affect menstrual cycles. Though virilizing tumors can 
cause amenorrhoea, other features of virilization such as hirsutism, flattening of breasts, and 
enlargement of the clitoris are generally present. 757 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Though ectopic pregnancy may be suspected here, the tube is likely to rupture with 
exacerbation of pain, bleeding, and peritonitis before six months of gestation. Additionally, the 
absence of vaginal bleeding/spotting, and the presence of weight loss makes the diagnosis 
unlikely. Option D: Submucous fibroid is associated with menorrhagia. First 2 months

questions.question:
Question 7: A gynaecologist suspects tuberculous salpingitis in a young woman and suggests some 
investigations to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is true about these 
investigations?

options.a: A differential WBC count shows lymphocytosis in advanced disease.
options.b: The ESR is frequently raised and is non-specific in early disease.
options.c: The Mantoux test is positive and indicative of current exposure to tubercle bacilli.
options.d: The Quantiferon test is positive and indicates latent tuberculosis.

questions.explanation:
The Quantiferon test will be positive in patients having genital TB. It is an indicator of latent 
tuberculosis. The Quantiferon test measures the release of interferon-gamma by T cells following 
stimulation by antigens unique to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. A differential WBC count shows lymphocytosis at all stages of genital tuberculosis. The ESR is 
frequently raised and is a non-specific investigation at any stage of the disease. None of these tests 
can be used for confirmation as these markers are raised in many infections. The Mantoux test is positive in 90% of cases of genital TB. It is indicative of past exposure to the 
tubercle bacilli. It is not a confirmatory investigation but a negative result indicates tuberculosis 
to be unlikely.

questions.question:
Question 8: 752 
Sold by @itachibot Hysterosalpingography was done in a young woman with infertility and menstrual 
abnormalities. Which of the following findings would not point towards a diagnosis of 
tubercular salpingitis?

options.a: A wedge shaped defect at the uterine isthmus
options.b: Beading and variations in filling defect
options.d: Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline

questions.explanation:
A wedge-shaped defect is not suggestive of tubercular salpingitis. It is seen at the uterine isthmus 
in patients with a history of Cesarean section with a uterine scar. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) features of genital tuberculosis are: • Lead pipe appearance due to rigid nonperistaltic pipe-like tube 758 
Sold by @itachibot • Beading and variation in filling defect • Calcification of the tube • Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx • Golf club appearance with slight or moderate dilatation of the ampullary portion of the fallopian 
tube. • Rosette type appearance secondary to multiple small diverticular like outpouching surrounding 
the ampulla produced by caseous ulceration. HSG is contraindicated in genital tuberculosis as it causes dissemination of the infection. This 
further increases the damage to the fallopian tubes. The investigation of choice in genital tuberculosis is an endometrial biopsy. The tubercle bacilli 
are present in the deeper layers of the endometrium. They come to the surface just before 
menstruation. Hence, an endometrial biopsy is done 1 or 2 days before menstruation. Menstrual blood can also be used for detecting mycobacteria. An HSG showing the features of tuberculous salpingitis is given below.

questions.question:
Question 9: The image below shows the hysterosalpingogram of a 37-year-old nulliparous woman. 
Identify the false statement about this finding.
questions.explanation:
The given image shows bilateral hydrosalpinx. It appears as a thin-walled structure. A hydrosalpinx is a chronic cystic swelling of the fallopian tube that forms after a distal tubal 
obstruction. The tubes are enormously distended due to filling with clear serous fluid and 
become retort-shaped. On histology, the tubal plicae appear flattened. The interstitial end of the 
tube is open whereas the fimbrial end is indrawn and closed. This permits the dye to enter but not 
exit the tube during HSG. It is caused due to: 759 
Sold by @itachibot • Pelvic inflammatory disease • Endometriosis • Tuberculosis - tubercular salpingitis may also cause tobacco-pouch appearance, lead pipe 
appearance and pyosalpinx • Fallopian tube neoplasms (rare) It can be an incidental finding during a pelvic exam or ultrasound. The patient may 
be asymptomatic, or present with infertility or chronic pelvic pain. On HSG, it appears as terminal sacculation and occlusion of both fallopian tubes with a normal 
uterine cavity. Usually, a thin-walled, hypoechoic, cystic structure is seen. However, it may appear 
as multiple hyperechoic mural nodules around the inner circumference of the tube creating a 
'beads on a string' appearance. Treatment: • Treat the underlying cause • Laparoscopic salpingostomy - in mild disease • IVF recommended for women with infertility and severe hydrosalpinx 760 
Sold by @itachibot Infertility
